words.meaning: Having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
examples: She gave a witty, entertaining, and articulate speech.
He is an articulate and persuasive speaker.

words.meaning: An object made by a human being, typically an item of cultural or historical interest.
examples: The museum is full of ancient Egyptian artifacts.
Archaeologists uncovered several stone artifacts at the site.

words.meaning: Clever or cunning devices or expedients, especially as used to trick or deceive others.
examples: The whole story was a clever artifice to fool the police.
I was impressed by the artifice of the novel's plot.

words.meaning: Without guile or deception; natural and simple.
examples: Her artless charm won her many friends.
He had an artless and innocent manner.

words.word: as broad as it is long
words.meaning: Used to say that it is impossible to choose between two things or situations because they are equal.
examples: Whether you take the highway or the back roads, it's as broad as it is long; both take 30 minutes.
You can pay now or later, but it's as broad as it is long since the total cost is the same.

words.meaning: To go up or climb.
examples: The climbers began to ascend the mountain.
Smoke ascended from the chimney.

words.meaning: Occupation of a position of dominant power or influence.
examples: The new political party is in the ascendancy.
His ideas gained ascendancy in the scientific community.

words.meaning: To find (something) out for certain; make sure of.
examples: The police are trying to ascertain the cause of the accident.
We need to ascertain whether the project is feasible.

words.meaning: Characterized by or suggesting the practice of severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence, typically for religious reasons.
examples: The monk lived an ascetic life of prayer and solitude.
He followed an ascetic diet, eating only simple foods.

words.meaning: To attribute something to (a cause, person, etc.).
examples: He ascribed his success to hard work.
The painting was ascribed to an unknown artist.

words.meaning: Free from contamination caused by harmful bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms.
examples: Surgical instruments must be kept in an aseptic environment.
The milk is packaged in aseptic cartons to keep it fresh.

words.meaning: Of the pale gray color of ash; (of a person's face) very pale with shock, fear, or illness.
examples: Her face was ashen with fear when she saw the intruder.
The sky had an ashen, gloomy look before the storm.

words.meaning: Extremely stupid or foolish.
examples: That was an asinine comment to make.
He kept asking asinine questions during the lecture.

words.meaning: With an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval.
examples: The old man looked askance at the teenagers' loud music.
They looked askance at our unconventional proposal.

words.meaning: Not in a straight or level position.
examples: His tie was slightly askew.
The picture on the wall was askew.

words.meaning: Harshness of tone or manner.
examples: She answered with asperity, clearly annoyed by the question.
He was known for the asperity of his critiques.

words.meaning: An attack on the reputation or integrity of someone or something.
examples: I don't think anyone is casting any aspersion on you.
He defended himself against the aspersion.

words.meaning: Plural of aspersion; attacks on the reputation or integrity of someone or something.
examples: He cast aspersions on his opponent's character.
She was upset by the aspersions cast on her work.

words.meaning: Having ambitions to achieve something, typically to follow a particular career.
examples: He is an aspirant to the throne.
The young aspirant hoped to become a famous actor.

words.meaning: A hope or ambition of achieving something.
examples: Her aspiration is to become a doctor.
He has high aspirations for his future.

words.meaning: To direct one's hopes or ambitions toward achieving something.
examples: She aspires to a career in medicine.
Many people aspire to own their own home.

words.meaning: To make a concerted or violent attack on.
examples: The rebels assailed the fortress.
He was assailed with questions from the reporters.

words.meaning: To determine the content or quality of (a metal or ore).
examples: The jeweler will assay the gold to determine its purity.
They decided to assay the new drug for its effectiveness.

words.meaning: Having or showing a confident and forceful personality.
examples: You need to be more assertive to get what you want.
She has an assertive and decisive manner.

words.meaning: To evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of.
examples: The committee will assess the applications.
It is important to assess the risks before starting a new business.

words.meaning: A useful or valuable thing, person, or quality.
examples: Her language skills are a great asset in her job.
The company's biggest asset is its loyal customer base.

words.meaning: Showing great care and perseverance.
examples: She was assiduous in her studies.
He is an assiduous worker who always does his best.

words.meaning: With great care and perseverance.
examples: She worked assiduously to complete the project on time.
He assiduously cultivated his connections in the industry.

words.meaning: To take in (information, ideas, or culture) and understand fully.
examples: It took her a long time to assimilate into the new culture.
Children can assimilate new information very quickly.

words.meaning: To make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense.
examples: He tried to assuage her guilt.
The letter assuaged his fears.

words.meaning: Great surprise.
examples: She stared at him in astonishment.
To my astonishment, he remembered my name.

words.meaning: Away from the correct path or direction.
examples: The young man was led astray by bad company.
The letter must have gone astray in the post.

words.meaning: (of a comment or style of speaking) sharp or severe.
examples: He made some astringent remarks about her performance.
Her astringent wit was not always appreciated.

words.meaning: Having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations or people and turn this to one's advantage.
examples: He was an astute businessman who made a fortune.
She made an astute observation about the political situation.

words.meaning: The protection granted by a nation to someone who has left their native country as a political refugee.
examples: He was granted asylum in the United States.
The family sought political asylum.

words.meaning: A tendency to revert to something ancient or ancestral.
examples: The building's design was an atavism, resembling ancient Roman architecture.
His violent outburst was seen as a form of atavism.

words.meaning: To make amends or reparation.
examples: He wanted to atone for his sins.
She tried to atone for her past mistakes by helping others.

words.meaning: (of body tissue or an organ) to waste away, typically due to the degeneration of cells.
examples: Muscles will atrophy if they are not used.
The doctor was concerned about the atrophy of the patient's leg muscles.

words.meaning: Paying close attention to something.
examples: The students were attentive during the lecture.
He is an attentive and caring host.

words.meaning: To reduce the force, effect, or value of.
examples: The new law is designed to attenuate the effects of the recession.
The sound was attenuated by the thick walls.

words.meaning: Unnaturally thin; weakened in force or effect.
examples: After the long illness, he was attenuated and frail.
The attenuated signal was difficult to detect.

words.meaning: To provide or serve as clear evidence of.
examples: The witness will attest to the defendant's alibi.
The high quality of the product attests to the skill of the workers.

words.meaning: The process of gradually reducing the strength or effectiveness of someone or something through sustained attack or pressure.
examples: The company is trying to reduce its workforce through attrition.
The war of attrition lasted for years.

words.meaning: Receptive or aware.
examples: She is attuned to the needs of her customers.
He is not very attuned to the feelings of others.

words.meaning: Not representative of a type, group, or class.
examples: His reaction was atypical for someone in his position.
The patient's symptoms were atypical of the disease.

words.meaning: Aware of what is going on; well informed.
examples: He is always au courant with the latest political news.
She likes to keep au courant with the latest fashion trends.

words.meaning: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks.
examples: It was an audacious plan to rob the bank.
She made an audacious claim that she could solve the problem.

words.meaning: A willingness to take bold risks; rude or disrespectful behavior.
examples: He had the audacity to ask for a raise after only a week on the job.
I can't believe she had the audacity to say that.

words.meaning: To make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
examples: He took a second job to augment his income.
The company plans to augment its workforce.

words.meaning: A sign of what will happen in the future; an omen.
examples: The flock of birds was a good augury for their journey.
The ancient Romans practiced augury to predict the future.

words.meaning: Respected and impressive.
examples: The august halls of the university were filled with students.
He was an august figure in the world of politics.

words.meaning: A divine or prophetic token.
examples: The project was started under a favorable auspice.
The meeting began under the best auspices.

words.meaning: Conducive to success; favorable.
examples: It was an auspicious beginning to the new year.
The timing of the launch was auspicious.

words.meaning: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance; (of living conditions or a way of life) having no comforts or luxuries.
examples: The headmaster was an austere and forbidding figure.
The monks lived an austere life in the monastery.

words.meaning: Favoring or enforcing strict obedience to authority, especially that of the government, at the expense of personal freedom.
examples: The country is ruled by an authoritarian regime.
He has an authoritarian style of management.

words.meaning: Able to be trusted as being accurate or true; reliable.
examples: This is the most authoritative book on the subject.
He is an authoritative source of information.

words.meaning: Relating to a ruler who has absolute power.
examples: The company was run by an autocratic manager.
The country suffered under the autocratic rule of the dictator.

words.meaning: A moving mechanical device made in imitation of a human being.
examples: The factory workers were like automatons, repeating the same task all day.
She moved like an automaton, with no emotion on her face.

words.meaning: Having the freedom to govern itself or control its own affairs.
examples: The region was granted autonomous status.
The company is an autonomous subsidiary of a larger corporation.

words.meaning: Independently; with the freedom to control one's own affairs.
examples: The university operates autonomously from the government.
Each department works autonomously.
